article.paragraph: Belarus(IPAc-enen-us-Belarus.oggbɛləˈruːsrespellbel-əROOSS';lang-beБелару́сь, tr.translbeBielaruś,IPA-bebʲɛlaˈrusʲIPA;lang-rusБелару́сьBelarus’bʲɪlɐˈrusʲ), officially theRepublic of Belarus, is alandlocked countryinEastern Europecite webhttp://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49regin.htm#europeStandard Country and Area Codes Classifications (M49)22 April 2010United Nations Organization1 April 2010UN Statistics Divisionhttps://web.archive.org/web/20100417070721/http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49regin.htm17 April 2010nobordered byRussiato the northeast,Ukraineto the south,Polandto the west, andLithuaniaandLatviato the northwest. Its capital isMinsk; other major cities includeBrest, BelarusBrest,HrodnaHrodna (Grodno),GomelHomiel (Gomel),MogilevMahilio (Mogilev)andVitebskVitsebsk (Vitebsk). Over 40% of itsconvert207600km2is forested. Its strongest economic sectors are service industries and manufacturing.cite webhttp://belstat.gov.by/homep/en/publications/belarus_in_figures/2012/about.phpContentsBelstat.gov.by4 October 2012

Until the 20th century, the lands of modern-day Belarus belonged to several countries, including thePrincipality of Polotsk, theGrand Duchy of Lithuania, thePolishLithuanian Commonwealth, and theRussian Empire. In the aftermath of theRussian Revolution (1917)Russian Revolution, Belarus declared independence as theBelarusian People's Republic, succeeded by theSocialist Soviet Republic of Byelorussia, which became a foundingRepublics of the Soviet Unionconstituent republic of the Soviet Unionand was renamed as theByelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic(Byelorussian SSR). Belarus lost almost half of its territory to Poland after thePolish-Soviet war. Much of the borders of Belarus took their modern shape in 1939 when some lands of theSecond Polish Republicwere reintegrated into it after theSoviet invasion of Polandand were finalized after World War II.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?idNational purpose in the world economy: post-Soviet states in comparative perspectiveAbdelalRawi2001[[Cornell University Press]]978-0-8014-3879-0cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?idEuropa World Year, Book 1Taylor & Francis Group2004[[Routledge|Europa publications]]978-1-85743-254-1During World War II, Belarus was devastated, losing about a third of its population and more than half of its economic resources.cite bookAxellAlbertRussia's Heroes, 1941–45Carroll & Graf Publishers20022470-7867-1011-XThe republic was redeveloped in the post-war years. In 1945, Belarus became a founding member of theUnited Nations, along with the Soviet Union and theUkrainian SSR.

The parliament of the republic declared thesovereigntyof Belarus onNowrap27 July1990, and during thedissolution of the Soviet Union, Belarus declared independence onNowrap25 August1991.cite webhttps://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.htmlThe World FactbookAlexander Lukashenkohas been the country's president since 1994. Lukashenko continued a number of Soviet-era policies, such asstate ownershipof large sections of the economy. Elections under Alexander Lukashenko have been widely criticized as being unfair, and according to many countries and organizations, political opposition has been violently suppressed.cite webhttp://www.osce.org/odihr/elections/belarus28 December 2010Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights – Elections – Belaruscite newshttp://www.economist.com/blogs/easternapproaches/2010/12/belaruss_election_0?fsrc28 December 2010Belarus's election: What should the EU do about Belarus? | The Economist27 December 2010cite webhttp://www.fco.gov.uk/en/news/latest-news/?view28 December 2010Foreign Secretary expresses UK concern following Belarus electionsIn 2000, Belarus and Russia signed a treaty for greater cooperation, with some hints of forming aUnion State. Belarus'sDemocracy Indexrating continuously ranks the lowest in Europe, the country is labelled as "Not Free" byFreedom House, "Repressed" in theIndex of Economic Freedom, and is rated as by far the worst country forpress freedomin Europe in thePress Freedom Index201314 Press Freedom Indexpublished byReporters Without Borders, where Belarus is ranked 157th out of an overall total of 180 nations.citation[[Reporters Without Borders]]Press Freedom Index 2013/2014January 2014http://rsf.org/index2014/en-index2014.php6 March 2014

Over 70% of Belarus's population of 9.49 million resides in urban areas. More than 80% of the population is ethnic Belarusian, with sizable minorities ofRussians,PolesandUkrainians. Since a referendum in 1995, the country has had two official languages:Belarusian languageBelarusianandRussian languageRussian. TheConstitution of Belarusdoes not declare any official religion, although the primary religion in the country isBelarusian Orthodox ChurchEastern Orthodox Christianity. The second most popular,Roman Catholicism in BelarusRoman Catholicism, has a much smaller following, although both Orthodox and Catholic versions of Christmas and Easter are celebrated asPublic holidays in Belarusnational holidays.
article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: The nameBelaruscorresponds literally with the termWhite Rus'. There are several claims to the origin of the nameWhite Rus'.HarvnbZaprudnik19932An ethno-religious theory suggests that the name used to describe the part of oldRuthenianlands within theGrand Duchy of Lithuaniathat had been populated mostly by early ChristianizedSlavs, as opposed toBlack Ruthenia, which was predominantly inhabited by pagan Balts.(Eng. "About the Origins of the Names of White and Black Ruthenia"), (Joseph Juho), 1956.An alternate explanation for the name comments on the white clothing worn by the local Slavic population.HarvnbMinahan199835A third theory suggests that the old Rus' lands that were not conquered by theTatars(i.e., Polatsk, Vitsiebsk and Mahilyow) had been referred to as "white." Other sources claim that, before 1267, the land not conquered by the Mongols was considered "White Rus'."

The nameRus' (region)Rus'is often conflated with its Latin formsRussiaandRuthenia, thus Belarus is often referred to asWhite RussiaorWhite Ruthenia. The name first appeared inMedieval German literatureGermanandMedieval Latin literatureLatinmedieval literature; the chronicles ofJan of Czarnkwmention the imprisonment of Lithuanian grand dukeJogailaand his mother at "Albae Russiae, Poloczk dicto" in 1381.HarvnbVauchezDobsonLapidge2001163In some languages, including German andDutch languageDutch, the country is generally called "White Russia" to this day (WeirusslandandWit-Ruslandrespectively).

The Latin term "Alba Russia" was used again byPope Pius VIto recognize theSociety of Jesusthere 1783, exclaiming "Approbo Societatem Jesu in Alba Russia degentem, approbo, approbo."Harvnbde Courson1879281The first known use ofWhite Russiato refer to Belarus was in the late-16th century by Englishman SirJerome Horsey, who was known for his close contacts with the Russian Royal Court.cite bookBelyAlies"The chronicle of the White Russia: an essay on the history of one geographical nameEncyclopedix2000Minsk, Belarus985-6599-12-1harvDuring the 17th century, the RussianTsarsused "White Rus" to describe the lands added from the Grand Duchy of Lithuania.HarvnbPlokhy2001327

article.paragraph: The termBelorussia(lang-runoБелору́ссия; the latter part similar but spelled and stressed differently from ,Russia) first rose in the days of theRussian Empire, and the Russian Tsar was usually styled "the Tsar of All the Russias", asRussiaor theRussian Empirewas formed by three parts of RussiatheGreat RussiaGreat,Little RussiaLittle, andWhite RussiaWhite.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/?idWhere Nation-States Come From: Institutional Change in the Age of NationalismPhilip G. Roeder15 December 2011978-0-691-13467-3This asserted that the territories are all Russian and all the peoples are also Russian; in the case of the Belarusians, they were variants of the Russian people.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/?idHandbook of Language and Ethnic Identity: The Success-Failure Continuum in Language and Ethnic Identity Efforts13 April 2011978-0-19-983799-1After theBolshevik Revolutionin 1917, the term White Russia caused some confusion as it was also the name of the military force that opposed the red Bolsheviks.HarvnbRichmond1995260During the period of the Byelorussian SSR, the termByelorussiawas embraced as part of a national consciousness. In western Belarus under Polish control,Byelorussiabecame commonly used in the regions of Biaystok and Grodno during the interwar period.cite bookIoffeGrigoryUnderstanding Belarus and How Western Foreign Policy Misses the MarkRowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc25 February 200841https://books.google.com/books?id0-7425-5558-5

The termByelorussia(its names in other languages such as English being based on the Russian form) was only used officially until 1991, when theSupreme Soviet of the Byelorussian SSRSupreme Sovietof the Byelorussian SSR decreed by law that the new independent republic should be calledRepublic of Belarus(" " spelled in Russian), as well its abridged form should be "Belarus". The law decreed that all the forms of the new term should be transliterated into other languages from theirBelarusian languageforms. The use of Byelorussian SSR and any abbreviations thereof were allowed from 1991 to 1993.cite webhttp://pravo.kulichki.com/zak/year1991/doc47159.htmLaw of the Republic of Belarus — About the name of the Republic of Belarus6 October 200719 September 1991Pravo — Law of the Republic of BelarusRussianConservative forces in the newly independent Belarus did not support the name change and opposed its inclusion in the 1991 draft of theConstitution of Belarus.HarvnbRyder1998183

Accordingly, the nameByelorussiawas replaced byBelarusin EnglishHarvnbZaprudnik19934–5and to some extent in Russian (although the traditional name persists in that language as well); likewise, the adjectiveBelorussianorByelorussianwas replaced byBelarusianin English (though Russian has not developed a new adjective).Belarusianis closer to the original Russian term ofbielaruski.Belarusian intelligentsia in the Stalin era attempted to change the name fromByelorussiato a form ofKriviabecause of the supposed connection with Russia.HarvnbTreadgoldEllison1999230Some nationalists also object to the name for the same reason.cite webhttp://euroradio.fm/en/swedish-government-urged-change-belarus-official-nameSwedish government urged to change Belarus' official name2 February 201013 July 2009European Radio for BelarusHarvnbLevySpilling200995However, several local popular newspapers kept the old name of the country in Russian in their names, for exampleKomsomolskaya PravdaKomsomolskaya Pravda v Byelorussii, which is the localized publication of a popular Russian newspaper. Also, those who wish for Belarus to be reunited with Russia continue to useBelorussia.Officially, the full name of the country is "Republic of Belarus" ( , , Respublika BelarusAudioRepublic of Belarus.ogglisten).cite webhttps://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.htmlBelarus – Government22 December 200713 December 2007[[The World Factbook]][[Central Intelligence Agency]]https://web.archive.org/web/20071211220928/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.html11 December 2007no
article.heading: History
Early history
article.paragraph: From 5000 to 2000 BC,Bandkeramikcultures predominated. In addition, remains from theDnieper-Donets culturewere found in Belarus and parts ofUkraine.cite bookShawIanJamesonRobertA Dictionary of ArchaeologyWiley2008203–204https://books.google.com/books?id978-0-470-75196-1Cimmeriansand other pastoralists roamed through the area by 1,000 BC, and by 500 AD, Slavs had taken up residence, which was circumscribed by theScythianswho roamed its outskirts. Invaders from Asia, among whom were theHunsandAvars (Carpathians)Avars, swept through c. 400600 AD, but were unable to dislodge the Slavic presence.Historical Atlas, Ancient and Classical World, by John Haywood, 1998

The region that is now Belarus was first settled byBaltic peoplesBaltictribes in the 3rd century. Around the 5th century, the area was taken over by Slavic tribes. The takeover was partially due to the lack of military coordination of the Balts but the gradual assimilation of the Balts into Slavic culture was peaceful in nature.harvnbZaprudnik19937
article.heading: Middle Ages
article.paragraph: In the 9th century the territory of modern Belarus became part ofKievan Rus', a vast East Slavic state ruled by theRurikiddynasty. Upon the death of Kievan Rus' rulerYaroslav I the Wise, the state split into independent principalities.cite bookPlokhySerhiiThe Origins of the Slavic NationsCambridge University Press200694–950-521-86403-8Many early Russian principalities were virtually razed or severely affected by a majorMongol invasion of Rus'Mongol invasionin the 13th century, but the lands of Belarus avoided the brunt of the invasion and were eventually absorbed by theGrand Duchy of Lithuania.cite bookRobinsonCharles HenryThe Conversion of EuropeLongmans, Green1917491–492

Although underNicholas I of RussiaNicholas IandAlexander III of RussiaAlexander IIIthe national cultures were repressed due to the policies of de-Polonizationru icon(Vossoyedineniye uniatov i istorieskiye sud'bi Belorusskogo naroda),Pravoslavie portalandRussification,ytko,Russian policy ..., p551.which included the return to Orthodoxy, the 19th century was signified by the rise of the modern Belarusian nation and self-confidence. A number of authors started publishing in the Belarusian language, includingJan Czeczot,Wadysaw SyrokomlaandKonstanty Kalinowski.

In aRussificationdrive in the 1840s,Nicholas I of RussiaNicholas Iprohibited the use of Belarusian language in public schools, campaigned against Belarusian publications and tried to pressure those who had converted to Catholicism under the Poles to reconvert to the Orthodox faith. In 1863, economic and cultural pressure exploded into aJanuary Uprisingrevolt, led by Kalinowski. After the failed revolt, the Russian government reintroduced the use ofCyrillic scriptCyrillicto Belarusian in 1864 and banned the use of theLatin alphabet.

During the negotiations of theTreaty of Brest-Litovsk, Belarus first declared independence under German occupation onNowrap25 March1918, forming theBelarusian People's Republic.harvnbBirgerson2002105–106cite bookIoffeGrigoryUnderstanding Belarus and How Western Foreign Policy Misses the MarkRowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc25 February 200857https://books.google.com/books?id0-7425-5558-5Immediately afterwards, thePolishSoviet Warignited, and the territory of Belarus was divided between Poland and the Soviet Russia.
article.heading: Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic
article.paragraph: FurtherByelorussian Soviet Socialist RepublicA part of Belarus under Russian rule emerged as theByelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic(Byelorussian SSR) in 1919. Soon thereafter it merged to form theLithuanianBelorussian Soviet Socialist RepublicLithuanian-Byelorussian SSR. The contested lands were divided between Poland and theSoviet Unionafter the war ended in 1921, and the Byelorussian SSR became a founding member of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in 1922.cite bookMarplesDavidBelarus: A Denationalized NationRoutledge19995https://books.google.com/books?id90-5702-343-1The western part of modern Belarus remained part of Poland.cite bookThe global and the local: understanding the dialectics of business systemsSorgeArndt2005[[Oxford University Press]]9780191535345cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?idMiniature empires: a historical dictionary of the newly independent statesMinahanJames1998[[Greenwood Publishing Group|Greenwood Press]]978-0-313-30610-5cite bookNick BaronPeter GatrellHomelandshttps://books.google.com/books?id18 September 201510 August 2004Anthem Press978-1-84331-385-419War, Population Displacement and State Formation in the Russian Borderlands 1914-1924

In the 1920s, agricultural reforms that culminated in the Belarusian phase of Sovietcollectivizationwere set in motion. In the 1930s, the implementation of the SovietFive-Year Plans for the National Economy of the Soviet Unionfive-year plans for the national economyled to rapid industrialization.

article.paragraph: In 1939,Nazi Germanyand the Soviet UnionInvasion of Polandinvaded and occupied Poland, marking the beginning ofWorld War II. Much of northeastern Poland, which had been part of the country since thePeace of Rigatwo decades earlier, was annexed to the Byelorussian SSR, and now constitutesWest Belarus.. . . ( ).-, 1940.. .., 1939.. .., 1939.80 .i i. .i, 2006.. 449474cite bookhttps://books.google.com/?idBelarus: The Last European DictatorshipAndrew Wilson2011978-0-300-13435-3The Soviet-controlled Byelorussian People's Council officially took control of the territories, whose populations consisted of a mixture of Poles, Ukrainians, Belarusians and Jews, on 28 October 1939 inBiaystok. Nazi GermanyOperation Barbarossainvaded the Soviet Unionin 1941. TheBrest Fortress, which had been annexed in 1939, at this time was subjected to one of the most destructive onslaughts that happened during the war. Statistically, the Byelorussian SSR was the hardest-hit Soviet republic in World War II; itOccupation of Belarus by Nazi Germanyremained in Nazi handsuntil 1944. During that time, Germany destroyed 209 out of 290 cities in the republic, 85% of the republic's industry, and more than one million buildings.

World War II casualties of the Soviet UnionCasualtieswere estimated to be between 2 and 3 million (about a quarter to one-third of the total population), while theHistory of the Jews in BelarusJewish population of Belaruswas devastated duringthe Holocaustand never recovered.cite webhttp://countrystudies.us/belarus/11.htmBelarus – Stalin and Russification26 March 2006FedorHelen1995Belarus: A Country Study[[Library of Congress]]The population of Belarus did not regain its pre-war level until 1971.It was also after this conflict that the final borders of Belarus were set by Stalin when parts of Belarusian territory were given to the recently annexed Lithuania.

After the war, Belarus was among the 51 founding countries of theUnited Nations Charterand as such it was allowed an additional vote at the UN, on top of the Soviet Union's vote. Vigorous postwar reconstruction promptly followed the end of the war and the Byelorussian SSR became a major center of manufacturing in western USSR, creating jobs and attracting ethnic Russians.cite webhttp://www.iexplore.com/travel-guides/europe/belarus/history-and-cultureBelarus History and Culture26 March 2006iExplore.comThe borders of the Byelorussian SSR and Poland were redrawn and became known as theCurzon Line.

Joseph Stalinimplemented a policy ofSovietizationto isolate the Byelorussian SSR fromWestern worldWestern influences.This policy involved sending Russians from various parts of the Soviet Union and placing them in key positions in the Byelorussian SSR government. The official use of theBelarusian languageand other cultural aspects were limited byPolitics of the Soviet UnionMoscow. After Stalin's death in 1953,Nikita Khrushchevcontinued his predecessor'scultural hegemonyprogram, stating, "The sooner we all start speaking Russian, the faster we shall build communism."

In 1986, the Byelorussian SSR was exposed to significantnuclear falloutfrom the explosion at theChernobyl disasterChernobylpower plant in the neighboringUkrainian Soviet Socialist RepublicUkrainian SSR.cite webhttp://countrystudies.us/belarus/12.htmBelarus- Perestroika26 March 2007FedorHelen1995Belarus: A Country Study[[Library of Congress]]

article.heading: Independence
article.paragraph: In March 1990, elections for seats in theSupreme Sovietof the Byelorussian SSR took place. Though the pro-independenceBelarusian Popular Fronttook only 10% of the seats, the populace was content with the selection of the delegates.cite webhttp://countrystudies.us/belarus/39.htmBelarus – Prelude to Independence22 December 2007FedorHelen1995Belarus: A Country Study[[Library of Congress]]Belarus declared itself sovereign onNowrap27 July1990 by issuing theDeclaration of State Sovereignty of the Belarusian Soviet Socialist Republic. With the support of the Communist Party, the country's name was changed to the Republic of Belarus onNowrap25 August1991.Stanislau ShushkevichStanislav Shushkevich, the chairman of the Supreme Soviet of Belarus, met withBoris Yeltsinof Russia andLeonid Kravchukof Ukraine onNowrap8 December1991 inBiaowiea ForestBelavezhskaya Pushchato formally declare the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the formation of theCommonwealth of Independent States.

Natural resources includepeatdeposits, small quantities of oil and natural gas,granite, dolomite (limestone),marl, chalk, sand, gravel, and clay.About 70% of the radiation from neighboring Ukraine's 1986Chernobyl disasterChernobyl nuclear disasterentered Belarusian territory, and about a fifth of Belarusian land (principally farmland and forests in the southeastern regions) was affected by radiation fallout.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4485003.stmBBC NewsBelarus cursed by ChernobylSarahRainsford26 April 200526 March 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20060424152147/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4485003.stm24 April 2006noThe United Nations and other agencies have aimed to reduce the level of radiation in affected areas, especially through the use ofcaesiumbinders andrapeseedcultivation, which are meant to decrease soil levels ofcaesium-137.cite webhttp://chernobyl.undp.org/english/belarus.htmlhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080506084709/http://chernobyl.undp.org/english/belarus.html6 May 2008United NationsThe United Nations and Chernobyl – The Republic of Belarus20044 October 2007cite newsMarilynSmithEcological reservation in Belarus fosters new approaches to soil remediationInternational Atomic Energy Agencyhttp://tc.iaea.org/tcweb/news_archive/Chernobyl/ecoreserve/default.asp19 December 2007

Belarus borders five countries:Latviato the north,Lithuaniato the northwest,Polandto the west,Russiato the north and the east, andUkraineto the south. Treaties in 1995 and 1996 demarcated Belarus's borders with Latvia and Lithuania, but Belarus failed to ratify a 1997 treaty establishing the Belarus-Ukraine border.cite webhttp://www.gkpv.gov.by/en/state_border_en/delim_historyhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080603064946/http://www.gkpv.gov.by/en/state_border_en/delim_history3 June 2008State Border – Delimitation History22 December 20072006State Border Committee of the Republic of BelarusBelarus and Lithuania ratified final border demarcation documents in February 2007.cite webhttp://www.urm.lt/index.php?-1507529950Lithuania's Cooperation with Belarus19 December 2007Lithuanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs
article.heading: Governance
article.paragraph: MainPolitics of BelarusFile:Victory-square.jpgthumbVictory Square, MinskVictory SquareinMinsk250x250pxBelarus is apresidential systempresidentialrepublic, governed by aPresident of Belaruspresidentand theNational Assembly of BelarusNational Assembly. Theterm of officetermfor each presidency is five years. Under the 1994 constitution, the president could serve for only two terms as president, but aBelarusian referendum, 2004change in the constitution in 2004eliminated term limits.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3882843.stmProfile: Alexander Lukashenko30 April 20109 January 2007BBC NewsBritish Broadcasting Corporationhttps://web.archive.org/web/20100420191928/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3882843.stm20 April 2010noAlexander Lukashenkohas been the president of Belarus since 1994. In 1996, Lukashenko called for a controversial vote to extend the presidential term from five to seven years, and as a resultBelarusian presidential election, 2001the electionthat was supposed to occur in 1999 was pushed back to 2001. TheBelarusian referendum, 1996referendum on the extensionwas denounced as a "fantastic" fake by the chief electoral officer,Viktar Hanchar, who was removed from office during the campaign.cite bookJeffries, Ian2004The countries of the former Soviet Union at the turn of the twenty-first century: the Baltic and European states in transitionRoutledge0-415-25230-X274The National Assembly is abicameralismbicameral parliamentcomprising the 110-memberHouse of Representatives of BelarusHouse of Representatives(the lower house) and the 64-memberCouncil of the Republic of BelarusCouncil of the Republic(the upper house).

The House of Representatives has the power to appoint theList of Belarusian Prime Ministersprime minister, make constitutional amendments, call for aMotion of Confidencevote of confidenceon the prime minister, and make suggestions on foreign and domestic policy.cite webBelarus 1994 (rev. 2004)https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Belarus_2004?langConstitute17 March 2015The Council of the Republic has the power to select various government officials, conduct an impeachment trial of the president, and accept or reject the bills passed by the House of Representatives. Each chamber has the ability to veto any law passed by local officials if it is contrary to the constitution.cite webhttp://www.president.gov.by/en/press19332.html#docSection IV:The President, Parliament, Government, the Courts22 December 20072004[[Constitution of Belarus]]Press Service of the President of the Republic of Belarushttps://web.archive.org/web/20071217035445/http://www.president.gov.by/en/press19332.html17 December 2007

The government includes a Council of Ministers, headed by the prime minister and five deputy prime ministers.cite webhttp://www.government.by/en/eng_sostav1.htmlDeputy Prime Ministers of the Republic of Belarus21 April 20102010Council of Ministers of the Republic of Belarushttps://web.archive.org/web/20100304020325/http://www.government.by/en/eng_sostav1.html4 March 2010The members of this council need not be members of the legislature and are appointed by the president. The judiciary comprises theSupreme Court of BelarusSupreme Courtand specialized courts such as theConstitutional Court of BelarusConstitutional Court, which deals with specific issues related to constitutional and business law. The judges of national courts are appointed by the president and confirmed by the Council of the Republic. For criminal cases, the highest court of appeal is the Supreme Court. The Belarusian Constitution forbids the use of special extrajudicial courts.

In theBelarusian parliamentary election, 2012, 105 of the 110 members elected to the House of Representatives were not affiliated with any political party. TheCommunist Party of Belaruswon 3 seats, and theAgrarian Party (Belarus)Agrarian PartyandRepublican Party of Labour and Justice, one each.cite webhttp://www.parties-and-elections.eu/belarus.htmlBelarusParties and Elections in Europe2012Wolfram Nordsieck18 March 2015Most non-partisans represent a wide scope of social organizations such as workers' collectives, public associations, and civil society organizations, similar to the composition of the Soviet legislature.cite webhttp://kibristasosyalistgercek.net/english/localGov/local_gov.htmlhttps://web.archive.org/web/20090221062403/http://kibristasosyalistgercek.net/english/localGov/local_gov.html21 February 2009SOVIET LOCAL GOVERNMENT18 July 2010RUSSIA TODAY SOCIETY
article.heading: Election controversies
article.paragraph: Neither the pro-Lukashenko parties, such as theBelarusian Socialist Sporting Partyand theRepublican Party of Labour and Justice, nor thePeople's Coalition 5 Plusopposition parties, such as thePartyja BPFBelarusian People's Frontand theUnited Civil Party of Belarus, won any seats in theElections in Belarus#Elections of 20042004 elections. Groups such as theOrganization for Security and Co-operation in Europe(OSCE) declared the election "un-free" because of the opposition parties' poor results and media bias in favor of the government.cite webhttp://www.osce.org/odihr/elections/belarus/38658PDFOSCE Report on the October 2004 parliamentary electionsDecember 2004Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe21 March 2007

In theBelarusian presidential election, 20062006 presidential election, Lukashenko was opposed byAlaksandar Milinkievi, who represented a coalition of opposition parties, and byAlaksandar Kazulinof the Social Democrats. Kazulin was detained and beaten by police during protests surrounding theAll Belarusian People's Assembly. Lukashenko won the election with 80% of the vote; the Russian Federation and the CIS deemed the vote open and faircite webhttp://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?linkBelarus in the aftermath of the Presidential election of 19 March 200625 May 201011 April 2006PDFParliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europewhile the OSCE and other organizations called the election unfair.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4766024.stm2 March 2006Belarus rally marred by arrestsBBC News26 March 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20060313155728/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4766024.stm13 March 2006no

After the December completion of theBelarusian presidential election, 20102010 presidential election, Lukashenko was elected to a fourth straight term with nearly 80% of the vote in elections. The runner-up opposition leaderAndrei Sannikovreceived less than 3% of the vote; independent observers criticized the election as fraudulent. When opposition protesters took to the streets inMinsk, many people, including most rival presidential candidates, were beaten and arrested by the state militia.cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/belarus/8224956/Police-guard-threatened-to-rape-Belarus-Free-Theatre-director-after-election-protest.htmlPolice guard threatened to rape Belarus Free Theatre director after election protestOliphantRoland25 December 2010The Daily Telegraph22 April 2011Londonhttps://web.archive.org/web/20110311053243/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/belarus/8224956/Police-guard-threatened-to-rape-Belarus-Free-Theatre-director-after-election-protest.html11 March 2011noMany of the candidates, including Sannikov, were sentenced to prison or house arrest for terms typically over four years.Belarus opposition leader Andrei Sannikov jailed,BBC News Online(14 May 2011)cite newshttp://www.kyivpost.com/news/russia/detail/93334/Belarus: 7 presidential candidates face 15 years[[Kyiv Post]]22 December 201023 December 2010https://web.archive.org/web/20110119193447/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/russia/detail/93334/19 January 2011noSix months later amidst an unprecedented economic crisis, activists utilized social networking to initiate a fresh round of protests characterized by wordless hand-clapping.cite newshttp://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2081858,00.htmMotlagh, JasonWhy Belarus' Dictator Is Not Fond of ApplauseTime8 July 20117 July 2011
article.heading: Corruption
article.paragraph: The judicial system in Belarus lacks independence and is subject to political interference.cite web2012 Human Rights Reports: Belarushttp://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2012/eur/204263.htmThe US Department of StateThe US Department of State17 November 2013Corrupt practices such as bribery often take place during tender processes, and whistleblower protection and national ombudsman are lacking in Belarus's anti-corruption system.cite webSnapshot of the Belarus Country Profilehttp://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/europe-central-asia/belarus/snapshot.aspxBusiness Anti-Corruption PortalGAN Integrity SolutionsHowever, there is a political will to fight against corruption in the government, and the government has made some progress in combating corruption, such as minimizing tax regulations in order to improve transparency in the tax office.cite webDoing Business 2014– Belarushttp://www.doingbusiness.org/The World Bank & IFCThe World Bank & IFC
article.heading: Human rights

link.part: A symbol of Belarusian opposition, this flag served as the national flag from 1991 to 1995.

article.paragraph: Lukashenko has described himself as having an "authoritarian ruling style".Western countries have described Belarus under Lukashenko as a dictatorship; the government has accused the same Western powers of trying to oust Lukashenko.cite newsStephenMulveyProfile: Europe's last dictator?10 September 2001British Broadcasting Corporationhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/116265.stmBBC News21 December 2007TheCouncil of Europehas barred Belarus from membership since 1997 for undemocratic voting and election irregularities in the November 1996 constitutional referendum and parliament by-elections.cite webhttp://press.coe.int/cp/97/11a(97).htmBelarus suspended from the Council of Europe17 January 1997Press Service of the Council of Europe26 March 2006

The Belarusian government is also criticized for human rights violations and its persecution of non-governmental organisations, independent journalists, national minorities, and opposition politicians.In a testimony to theUnited States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, formerUnited States Secretary of StateCondoleezza Ricelabeled Belarus as one of the world's six "outposts of tyranny".cite webhttp://foreign.senate.gov/testimony/2005/RiceTestimony050118.pdfOpening Statement by Dr. Condoleezza Rice, Senate Foreign Relations Committee18 January 2005PDF26 March 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20060325002023/http://foreign.senate.gov/testimony/2005/RiceTestimony050118.pdf25 March 2006In response, the Belarusian government called the assessment "quite far from reality".cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4187361.stm19 January 2005At-a-glance: 'Outposts of tyranny'26 March 2006BBC NewsTheViasna Human Rights Centrelists 11 political prisonerscite webhttp://spring96.org/en/news/49539List of political prisoners | The Human Rights Center "Viasna"Spring96.org2013-03-26currently detained in Belarus. Among them is the human rights activistAles Bialiatski, Vice President ofInternational Federation for Human Rightsand head of Viasna.cite webhttp://freeales.fidh.net/why-is-ales-bialiatski-in-jail/Why Ales Bialiatski is in jail?Belarus: Civil Society Under Attack18 March 2015

Lukashenko announced a new law in 2014 that will prohibitkolkhozworkers (around 9% of total work force) from leaving their jobs at willa change of job and living location will require permission from governors. The law was compared withserfdomby Lukashenko himself.cite webhttp://charter97.org/en/news/2014/5/28/100271/Lukashenka promises "serfdom" in villages2014Charter '97cite webhttp://wyborcza.pl/1,75477,16075099,Panszczyzna_u_Lukaszenki__Prezydent_Bialorusi_chce.htmlPańszczyzna u Łukaszenki. Prezydent Białorusi chce zakazać kołchoźnikom odchodzić z pracy2014Gazeta WyborczaPolishSimilar regulations were introduced for the forestry industry in 2012.cite webhttp://belsat.eu/en/wiadomosci/a,11316,in-chase-of-upgrade-serfdom-for-woodworkers.htmlIn chase of upgrade: serfdom for woodworkers?2012[[Belsat]]
article.heading: Foreign relations
article.paragraph: MainForeign relations of BelarusFile:CSTO Collective Security Council meeting Kremlin, Moscow 2012-12-19 01.jpegthumbrightPresidentAlexander Lukashenko, right, shaking hands withPresident of RussiaRussian PresidentVladimir Putin, left, in 2012Belarus and Russia have been close trading partners and diplomatic allies since the breakup of the Soviet Union. Belarus is dependent on Russia for imports of raw materials and for its export market.cite webhttp://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5371.htmBackground Note: Belarus7 November 2007United States State Department2007United States Governmenthttps://web.archive.org/web/20071114000028/http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5371.htm14 November 2007noThe union of Russia and Belarus, a supranational confederation, was established in a 199699 series of treaties that called for monetary union, equal rights, single citizenship, and a common foreign and defense policy.However, the future of the union has been placed in doubt because of Belarus's repeated delays of monetary union, the lack of a referendum date for the draft constitution, and a2007 RussiaBelarus energy disputedispute over the petroleum trade.

On 11 December 2007, reports emerged that a framework for the new state was discussed between both countries.cite newsAPReutersRussia-Belarus Union Presidency Dismissed10 December 2007http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/russia-belarus-union-presidency-dismissed/351790.htmlThe Moscow Times13 December 2007OnNowrap27 May2008, Belarusian President Lukashenko said that he had namedPrime Minister of RussiaRussian Prime MinisterVladimir Putinthe "prime minister" of the Russia-Belarus alliance. The significance of this act was not immediately clear; some incorrectly speculated that Putin would become president of a unified state of Russia and Belarus after stepping down as Russian president in May 2008.cite newsAssociated PressPutin named PM of Belarus-Russia alliance27 May 2008http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/2483910727 May 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080528032859/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/2483910728 May 2008no

Belarus was a founding member of theCommonwealth of Independent States(CIS); however, recently other CIS members have questioned the effectiveness of the organization.cite webhttp://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2006/11/6e49cd34-6c37-40ff-87f4-a6557e84f7e9.htmlCIS: Foreign Ministers, Heads Of State Gather In Minsk For Summit7 November 20072006Radio Free Europehttps://web.archive.org/web/20071116014000/http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2006/11/6e49cd34-6c37-40ff-87f4-a6557e84f7e9.html16 November 2007noBelarus has trade agreements with severalEuropean Unionmember states (despite other member states' travel ban on Lukashenko and top officials),cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2492939.stmEU imposes Belarus travel ban3 December 2007BBC19 November 2002BBC Newsincluding neighboring Latvia, Lithuania, and Poland.cite webhttp://www.mfa.gov.by/en/foreign-policy/https://web.archive.org/web/20080217002512/http://mfa.gov.by/en/foreign-policy/17 February 2008Foreign Policy22 December 20072007Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of BelarusIncidentally, the travel bans imposed by the European Union have been lifted in the past in order to allow Lukashenko to attend diplomatic meetings and also to engage his government and opposition groups in dialogue.cite newsBelarus president visits Vatican27 April 2009British Broadcasting Corporationhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8021513.stmBBC News30 April 2010

File:Normandy format talks in Minsk (February 2015) 03.jpegthumbLeaders of Belarus, Russia, Germany, France, and Ukraine at the summit inMinsk IIMinsk, 1112 February 2015Bilateral relations with the United States are strained because theUnited States Department of StateU.S. Department of Statesupports various anti-Lukashenko non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and also because the Belarusian government has made it increasingly difficult for U.S.-based organizations to operate within the country.cite webhttp://belarus.usembassy.gov/assistance1997.htmlU.S. Government Assistance FY 97 Annual Report22 December 20071998United States Embassy in Minsk, BelarusDiplomatic relations remained tense, and in 2004, the United States passed theBelarus Democracy Act of 2004Belarus Democracy Act, which authorized funding for anti-government Belarusian NGOs, and proscribed loans to the Belarusian government, except for humanitarian purposes.cite newsBelarus Democracy Act Will Help Cause of Freedom, Bush Says22 October 2007United States State Departmenthttp://usinfo.state.gov/dhr/Archive/2004/Oct/22-739373.htmlUSINO22 December 2007Despite this political friction, the two countries do cooperate on intellectual property protection, prevention of human trafficking, technology crime, and disaster relief.cite webhttp://www.mfa.gov.by/en/foreign-policy/bilateral/e14c28c31d21a670.htmlRelations between Belarus and the United States of America22 December 20072006Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Belarushttps://web.archive.org/web/20071205042327/http://www.mfa.gov.by/en/foreign-policy/bilateral/e14c28c31d21a670.html5 December 2007

Sino-Belarusian relations have improved,cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/business/feedarticle/9003481China's Xi promises Belarus $1 billion in loansGuardian2013-04-29London7 May 2008strengthened by the visit of President Lukashenko to China in October 2005.cite newsLetianPanChina, Belarus agree to upgrade economic ties6 December 2005Xinhua News Agencyhttp://english.gov.cn/2005-12/06/content_119410.htm22 December 2007Belarus also has strong ties withSyria,cite newsSyria and Belarus agree to promote trade13 March 1998BBChttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/65106.stmBBC News22 December 2007considered a key partner in the Middle East.cite newsBelarus-Syria report substantial progress in trade and economic relations31 August 2007Press Service of the President of the Republic of Belarushttp://www.president.gov.by/en/press32193.html22 December 2007https://web.archive.org/web/20080120063008/http://www.president.gov.by/en/press32193.html20 January 2008noIn addition to the CIS, Belarus is a member of theEurasian Economic Community, theCollective Security Treaty Organisation,the internationalNon-Aligned Movementsince 1998,cite webhttp://www.mfa.gov.by/en/foreign-policy/international-organizations/a25183575d762f8b.htmlhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080511155330/http://www.mfa.gov.by/en/foreign-policy/international-organizations/a25183575d762f8b.html11 May 2008Membership of the Republic of Belarus in International Organizations4 November 20072007Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the RBtheOrganization on Security and Cooperation in Europe(OSCE), and the UN since its founding in 1945. As an OSCE member state, Belarus's international commitments are subject to monitoring under the mandate of theU.S. Helsinki Commission.cite webhttp://www.un.org/members/growth.shtmlGrowth in United Nations membership, 1945–present22 December 20073 July 2006Department of Public Information[[United Nations|United Nations Organization]]https://web.archive.org/web/20071216164953/http://www.un.org/members/growth.shtml16 December 2007no
Belarus is included in the European Union'sEuropean Neighbourhood Policy(ENP) which aims at bringing the EU and its neighbours closer.

article.paragraph: Major General Andrei Ravkov heads the Ministry of Defense,cite webhttp://www.mil.by/en/forces/squad/Leaders18 March 20152015Ministry of Defense of the Republic of Belarusand Alexander Lukashenko (as president) serves as Commander-in-Chief.The Armed Forces were formed in 1992 using parts of the formerSoviet Armed Forceson the new republic's territory. The transformation of the ex-Soviet forces into the Armed Forces of Belarus, which was completed in 1997, reduced the number of its soldiers by 30,000 and restructured its leadership and military formations.cite webhttp://www.mod.mil.by/7okrugarmia.htmlHistory22 December 20072006Ministry of Defense of the Republic of BelarusRussianhttps://web.archive.org/web/20071217010640/http://www.mod.mil.by/7okrugarmia.html17 December 2007no

Most of Belarus's service members areconscriptionconscripts, who serve for 12 months if they have higher education or 18 months if they do not.Routledge,International Institute for Strategic StudiesIISSMilitary Balance 2007, pp.158159Demographic decreases in the Belarusians of conscription age have increased the importance of contract soldiers, who numbered 12,000 in 2001.cite webhttp://mdb.cast.ru/mdb/5-2001/dp/mdafb/Military Development and the Armed Forces of Belarus9 October 2007BykovskyPavelAlexander VasilevichMay 2001Moscow Defense BriefIn 2005, about 1.4% of Belarus's gross domestic product was devoted to military expenditure.cite webhttps://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.htmlBelarus – Military9 October 20072005The World FactbookCentral Intelligence Agencyhttps://web.archive.org/web/20071009182107/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.html9 October 2007no

Belarus has not expressed a desire to joinNATObut has participated in the Individual Partnership Program since 1997,cite webhttp://www.mfa.gov.by/en/foreign-policy/multilateral/c21ec980e0def482.htmlhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080511162152/http://www.mfa.gov.by/en/foreign-policy/multilateral/c21ec980e0def482.html11 May 2008Belarus and NATO9 October 20072002Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Belarusand Belarus provides refueling and airspace support for theISAFmission inAfghanistan.cite webhttp://www.mfa.gov.by/en/organizations/membership/list/c6eaf2b20c037582.htmlNorth Atlantic Treaty Organization30 April 20102009The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of BelarusBelarus first began to cooperate with NATO upon signing documents to participate in their Partnership for Peace Program in 1995.cite webhttp://www.mfa.gov.by/en/press/news_mfa/c6f560f2f8d745ee.htmlNATO Council adopted individual partnership program with Belarus30 April 201011 March 2002The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of BelarusHowever, Belarus cannot join NATO because it is a member of theCollective Security Treaty Organisation. Tensions between NATO and Belarus peaked after the March 2006 presidential election in Belarus.cite webhttp://ru.forsecurity.org/nato-and-belarus-partnership-past-tensions-and-future-possibilitiesNato and Belarus – partnership, past tensions and future possibilities25 November 201021 November 2010Laurie Walker, NATO–Belarus Desk Officer, Political Affairs and Security Policy Division, NATO Headquarters
article.heading: Administrative divisions
article.paragraph: Belarus is divided into sixOblastregions(lang-beвобласць,lang-runoо́бласть), which are named after the cities that serve as their administrative centers.cite webhttp://www.president.gov.by/en/press19329.htmlSection I: Principles of the Constitutional System. Published 1994, amended in 199622 December 20072004[[Constitution of Belarus]]Press Service of the President of the Republic of Belarushttps://web.archive.org/web/20071217035739/http://www.president.gov.by/en/press19329.html17 December 2007Each region has a provincial legislative authority, called a region council (lang-beабласны Савет Дэпутатаў,lang-runoобластно́й Сове́т Депутатов), which is elected by its residents, and a provincial executive authority called a region administration (lang-beабласны выканаўчы камітэт,lang-runoобластно́й исполнительный комите́т), whose chairman is appointed by the president.cite webhttp://www.president.gov.by/en/press19333.htmlSection V: Local government and self-government22 December 20072004[[Constitution of Belarus]]Press Service of the President of the Republic of Belarushttps://web.archive.org/web/20071217035739/http://www.president.gov.by/en/press19333.html17 December 2007Regions are further subdivided intoraions, commonly translated asdistricts(lang-beраён,lang-runoрайон).

Eachraionhas its own legislative authority, orraioncouncil, (lang-beраённы Савет Дэпутатаў,lang-runoрайонный Сове́т Депутатов) elected by its residents, and an executive authority orraionadministration appointed by higher executive powers. There are six regions, divided into 118raions.cite webKey FactsPress Service of the President of the Republic of Belarus2015http://president.gov.by/en/facts-en/The city of Minsk is split into nine districts and enjoys special status as the nation's capital.cite webhttp://www.minsk.gov.by/en/tempage/minsk/About Minsk27 April 201016 December 2009Minsk City Executive CommitteeIt is run by an executive committee and has been granted a charter of self-rule.cite webhttp://www.minsk.gov.by/cgi-bin/gor_ind.pl?&langAbout Minsk20 December 2007Minsk City Executive Committee

article.paragraph: Most of the Belarusian economy remainsstate capitalismstate-controlledand has been described as "Soviet-style."cite newsBelarus shuns Moscow amid loan rowAl Jazeera English29 May 200930 May 2009Belarus' Soviet-style economy has been propped up in part by cheap Russian gas and oil and Lukashenko has called for his country to reunite with Russia.http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2009/05/2009529121949669957.htmlIn 2006, 51.2% of Belarusians were employed by state-controlled companies, 47.4% were employed by private companies (of which 5.7% were partially foreign-owned), and 1.4% were employed by foreign companies.cite webhttp://belstat.gov.by/homep/en/indicators/labor.phpLabour6 November 20072006Ministry of Statistics and Analysis of the Republic of Belarushttps://web.archive.org/web/20071011152228/http://belstat.gov.by/homep/en/indicators/labor.php11 October 2007yesThe country relies on Russia for various imports, including petroleum.cite webhttp://www.nato.int/acad/fellow/99-01/martinsen.pdfThe Russian-Belarusian Union and the Near Abroad7 November 2007NATO2002Dr. Kaare Dahl MartinsenNorwegian Institute for Defence StudiesPDFhttps://web.archive.org/web/20071127003300/http://www.nato.int/acad/fellow/99-01/martinsen.pdf27 November 2007nocite newsRussia may cut oil supplies to ally Belarus – Putin25 October 2006Reutershttp://uk.reuters.com/article/2006/10/25/energy-russia-belarus-idUKL25566340200610258 October 2007Important agricultural products include potatoes and cattle byproducts, including meat.In 1994, Belarus's main exports included heavy machinery (especiallyBelarus (tractor)tractors), agricultural products, and energy products.cite webhttp://countrystudies.us/belarus/36.htmBelarus – Exports4 November 20071994Library of CongressCountry Studies

Historically, textiles and wood processing have constituted a large part of industrial activity.cite webhttp://www.mfa.gov.by/docs/eio/2007eng.pdfEconomic and Investment Review22 December 2007Ministry of the Economy of the Republic of Belarus2007PDFMinistry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of BelarusAt the time of the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, Belarus was one of the world's most industrially developed states by percentage of GDP as well as the richest CIS member-state.World Bank. "Belarus: Prices, Markets, and Enterprise Reform,"p. 1. World Bank, 1997. ISBN 0-8213-3976-1Economically, Belarus involved itself in the CIS,Eurasian Economic Community, andUnion StateUnion with Russia.

In the 1990s, however, industrial production plunged due to decreases in imports, investment, and demand for Belarusian products from its trading partners.cite webhttp://countrystudies.us/belarus/30.htmBelarus – Industry8 October 20071995Country StudiesLibrary of CongressGDP only began to rise in 1996;cite webhttp://lnweb18.worldbank.org/eca/eca.nsf/2656afe00bc5f02185256d5d005dae97/8ec2dc1ef03aed3e85256d5d0067dc90?OpenDocumentBelarus – Country Brief 20039 November 20072006World Bankhttps://web.archive.org/web/20071210182026/http://lnweb18.worldbank.org/ECA/eca.nsf/2656afe00bc5f02185256d5d005dae97/8ec2dc1ef03aed3e85256d5d0067dc90?OpenDocument10 December 2007nothe country was the fastest-recovering former Soviet republic in the terms of its economy.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?idTransition: The First DecadeIn 2006, GDP amounted toNowrapUS$83.1 billioninpurchasing power parity(PPP) dollars (estimate), or about $8,100 per capita.cite webhttps://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.htmlThe World Factbook – Belarus – Economy8 October 20072006Central Intelligence Agencyhttps://web.archive.org/web/20071009182107/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.html9 October 2007noIn 2005, GDP increased by 9.9%; the inflation rate averaged 9.5%.

In 2006, Belarus's largest trading partner was Russia, accounting for nearly half of total trade, with the European Union the next largest trading partner, with nearly a third of foreign trade.Foreign trade in goods and services in Belarus up by 11.5% in JanuaryOctober, Council of Ministerswaybackhttp://www.government.by/en/eng_analytics11.html20090104060950Because of its failure to protect labour rights, however, Belarus lost its EUGeneralized System of Preferencesstatus onNowrap21 June2007, which raised tariff rates to their priormost favoured nationlevels.The EU's Relationship With Belarus  Tradewaybackhttp://ec.europa.eu/external_relations/belarus/pdf/belarus_trade_en.pdf20120131135151Belarus applied to become a member of theWorld Trade Organizationin 1993.cite webhttp://www.wto.org/English/thewto_e/acc_e/a1_belarus_e.htmAccessions – BelarusWto.org2013-04-29

The labour force consists of more than four million people, among whom women hold slightly more jobs than men.In 2005, nearly a quarter of the population was employed by industrial factories.Employment is also high in agriculture, manufacturing sales, trading goods, and education. The unemployment rate, according to government statistics, was 1.5% in 2005.There were 679,000 unemployed Belarusians, two-thirds of whom were women.The unemployment rate has been in decline since 2003, and the overall rate of employment is the highest since statistics were first compiled in 1995.

The currency of Belarus is theBelarusian ruble(BYR). The currency was introduced in May 1992, replacing theSoviet ruble. The first coins of the Republic of Belarus were issued on 27 December 1996.cite webBanknotes and Coins of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarushttp://www.nbrb.by/engl/CoinsBanknotes/National Bank of the Republic of BelarusThe ruble was reintroduced with new values in 2000 and has been in use ever since.cite webhttp://www.nbrb.by/engl/CoinsBanknotes/History of the Belarusian rubleNational Bank of the Republic of Belarus2013-04-29As part of theUnion StateUnion of Russia and Belarus, both states have discussed using a single currency along the same lines as the Euro. This led to a proposal that the Belarusian ruble be discontinued in favour of theRussian ruble(RUB), starting as early asNowrap1 January2008. TheNational Bank of the Republic of BelarusNational Bank of Belarusabandoned pegging the Belarusian ruble to the Russian ruble in August 2007.cite webhttp://english.pravda.ru/world/ussr/23-08-2007/96292-belarus_russia-0Belarus abandons pegging its currency to Russian rubleEnglish.pravda.ru2007-08-232013-04-29

The banking system of Belarus consists of thirty state-owned banks and one privatised bank.cite webhttp://www.heritage.org/research/features/index/country.cfm?idHeritage Foundation's Index of Economic Freedom – Belarus18 March 2007https://web.archive.org/web/20070223175533/http://www.heritage.org/research/features/index/country.cfm?id23 February 2007noOn 23 May 2011, the Belarusian ruble depreciated 56% against the U.S. dollar. The depreciation was even steeper on the black market and financial collapse seemed imminent as citizens rushed to exchange their rubles for dollars, euros, durable goods, and canned goods.cite webYURAS KARMANAU, Associated Presshttp://seattletimes.com/html/businesstechnology/2015143616_apeubelaruscrisis.htmlBelarus devaluation spreads panicSeattle Times25 May 201127 May 2011On 1 June 2011, Belarus requested an economic rescue package from theInternational Monetary Fund.With economy in tatters, Belarus appeals to IMF for rescue loan of up to $8 billion, Associated Press, 1 June 2011. article.heading: Demographics
article.paragraph: MainDemographics of BelarusAccording to the 2009 census, the population is 9,503,807.cite webPopulation census 2009http://belstat.gov.by/homep/en/census/2009/pc2009.phpbelstat.gov.by15 February 2013EthnicBelarusiansconstitute 83.7% of Belarus's total population.The next largest ethnic groups are:Russians(8.3%),Poles(3.1%), andUkrainians(1.7%).Belarus has a population density of about 50 people per square kilometer (127 per sq mi); 70% of its total population is concentrated in urban areas.cite webhttp://un.by/en/aboutbelarus/population/About Belarus – Population7 October 20072003United Nations Office in Belarushttps://web.archive.org/web/20071017223223/http://un.by/en/aboutbelarus/population/17 October 2007noMinsk, the nation's capital and largest city, was home to 1,937,900 residentsas of2015in 2015.cite webhttp://belstat.gov.by/ofitsialnaya-statistika/otrasli-statistiki/naselenie/demografiya_2/operativnaya-informatsiya_1/o-demograficheskoi-situatsii/o-demograficheskoi-situatsii-v-yanvare-marte-2015-g/О демографической ситуации в январе-марте 2015 г.About demographic situation in January–March 2015RussianGomel, with a population of 481,000, is the second-largest city and serves as the capital of the Homiel Voblast. Other large cities areMogilev(365,100),Vitebsk(342,400),Hrodna(314,800) andBrest, BelarusBrest(298,300).cite webhttp://www.world-gazetteer.com/wg.php?xLargest Cities of Belarus (2007)World-gazetteer.com2013-04-29

Like many other European countries, Belarus has a negative population growth rate and a negative natural growth rate. In 2007, Belarus's population declined by 0.41% and itsTotal fertility ratefertility ratewas 1.22,cite webhttps://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.htmlCIA World Factbook (2007) – Belarus – People7 November 2007https://web.archive.org/web/20071114004238/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.html14 November 2007nowellSub-replacement fertilitybelow the replacement rate. Itsnet migration rateis +0.38 per 1,000, indicating that Belarus experiences slightly more immigration than emigration.As of2006, 69.7% of Belarus's population is aged 14 to 64; 16% is under 14, and 14.6% is 65 or older. Its population is also aging; the median age of 37 is estimated to rise to between 55 and 65 in 2050.cite webhttp://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/populationPyramid.php?BO/2050Population Pyramids—Belarus (2050)26 April 20102006JPEGU.S. Census BureauThere are about 0.87 males per female in Belarus.The average life expectancy is 68.7 years (63.0 years for males and 74.9 years for females).Over 99% of Belarusians aged 15 and older areliterate.

article.paragraph: Belarus's Catholic minority, which constitute about 9% of the country's populationand is concentrated in the western part of the country, especially aroundHrodna, is made up of a mixture of Belarusians and the country'sPolesPolishandLithuanian peopleLithuanianminorities.cite webhttp://countrystudies.us/belarus/20.htmBelarus – ReligionIn a statement to the media regarding Belarusian-Vatican ties, President Lukashenko stated that Orthodox and Catholic believers are the "two main confessors in our country".cite webhttp://news.belta.by/en/news/president?idBelarus, Roman Catholic Church may ink cooperation agreement – PresidentNews.belta.by25 April 20094 October 2012The total Roman Catholic population has dropped to 12% of religious believers, according to a 2011 report by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

article.heading: Culture
Arts and literature
article.paragraph: File:Theatre opera&ballet, Minsk.JPGthumbTheNational Opera and Ballet of BelarusOpera and Ballet Theaterin MinskThe Belarusian government sponsors annual cultural festivals such as theSlavianski Bazaar in Vitebsk, which showcases Belarusian performers, artists, writers, musicians, and actors. Several state holidays, such asList of countries by Independence DayIndependence DayandVictory Day (9 May)Victory Day, draw big crowds and often include displays such as fireworks and military parades, especially in Vitebsk and Minsk.cite webhttp://www.belarusembassy.org/belarus/culture.htmBelarusian National CultureEmbassy of the Republic of Belarus in the United States of America26 March 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20060210203549/http://www.belarusembassy.org/belarus/culture.htm10 February 2006The government's Ministry of Culture finances events promoting Belarusian arts and culture both inside and outside the country.

File:Skaryna 1517.jpgthumbuprightrightFrancysk Skaryna, developer of the Belarusian language, and one of the first people to print in theCyrillicalphabetBelarusian literature began with 11th- to 13th-century religious scripture, such as the 12th-century poetry ofCyril of Turaw.cite webhttp://www.belarusguide.com/culture1/literature/Old_Poetry.htmlOld Belarusian Poetry9 October 20071994Virtual Guide to Belarushttps://web.archive.org/web/20071011050535/http://www.belarusguide.com/culture1/literature/Old_Poetry.html11 October 2007noBy the 16th century,PolotskresidentFrancysk Skarynatranslated the Bible into Belarusian. It was published inPragueandVilniussometime between 1517 and 1525, making it the first book printed in Belarus or anywhere in Eastern Europe."Belarus | history."Encyclopdia Britannica.Britannica.comThe modern era of Belarusian literature began in the late 19th century; one prominent writer wasYanka Kupala. Many Belarusian writers of the time, such asUadzimir yka, Kazimir Svayak,Yakub Kolas,mitrok Biadula, andMaksim Haretski, wrote forNasha Niva, a Belarusian-language paper published in Vilnius.

After Belarus was incorporated into the Soviet Union, the Soviet government took control of the Republic's cultural affairs. At first, a policy of "Belarusianization" was followed in the newly formed Byelorussian SSR. This policy was reversed in the 1930s, and the majority of prominent Belarusian intellectuals and nationalist advocates were either exiled or killed in Stalinist purges.cite journalTereshkovichPavelRobert J. ValliereThe Belarusian Road to ModernityInternational Journal of Sociology200131Belarus:Between the East and the West (I)378–8920628625The free development of literature occurred only in Polish-held territory until Soviet occupation in 1939.Several poets and authors went into exile after the Nazi occupation of Belarus and would not return until the 1960s.The last major revival of Belarusian literature occurred in the 1960s with novels published byVasil BykaandUladzimir Karatkievich. An influential author who devoted his work to awakening the awareness of the catastrophes the country has suffered, wasAles Adamovich. He was named bySvetlana Alexievich, the Belarusian winner of theNobel Prize in Literature2015, as "her main teacher, who helped her to find a path of her own".''Svetlana Alexievich: Voices from Big Utopia''

File:Wincenty Dunin-Marcinkiewicz 2.jpgthumbuprightleftPoet and librettistVintsent Dunin-MartsinkyevichMusic of BelarusMusic in Belaruslargely comprises a rich tradition of folk and religious music. The country's folk music traditions can be traced back to the times of theGrand Duchy of Lithuania. In the 19th century, Polish composerStanisaw Moniuszkocomposed operas and chamber music pieces while living in Minsk. During his stay, he worked with Belarusian poetVintsent Dunin-Martsinkyevichand created the operaSialanka(Peasant Woman). At the end of the 19th century, major Belarusian cities formed their own opera and ballet companies. The balletNightingale (ballet)Nightingaleby M. Kroshner was composed during the Soviet era and became the first Belarusian ballet showcased at the National Academic Vialiki Ballet Theatre in Minsk.cite newsCrystalZouBallets for Christmas11 December 2003http://app1.chinadaily.com.cn/star/2003/1211/wh28-1.htmlShanghai Star20 December 2007

After theSecond World War, music focused on the hardships of the Belarusian people or on those who took up arms in defense of the homeland. During this period,Anatoly Bogatyrev, creator of the operaIn Polesye Virgin Forest, served as the "tutor" of Belarusian composers.cite webhttp://www.belarusguide.com/culture1/music/Belarusian_composers_&_classical_music.htmClassical Music of BelarusBelarusguide.com2013-04-29The National Academic Theatre of Ballet, in Minsk, was awarded thePrix Benois de la DanseBenois de la Dance Prizein 1996 as the top ballet company in the world.Rock music has become increasingly popular in recent years, though the Belarusian government has attempted to limit the amount of foreign music aired on the radio in favor of traditional Belarusian music. Since 2004, Belarus has been sending artists to theEurovision Song Contest.National State TeleradiocompanyWaybackyes20080224183337http://www.tvr.by/eng/konkurs.aspPage on the 2004 Belarusian entry to the Eurovision Song Contest. Published 2004. Retrieved 18 March 2007.

The famous artistMarc Chagallwas born in Liozna (near the city ofVitebsk) in 1887, today Belarus. He spent theWorld War Iyears in Soviet Belarus, becoming one of the country's most distinguished artists and a member of the modernistavant-garde, founding the Vitebsk Arts College before leaving for Paris in 1922.
article.heading: Dress
article.paragraph: The traditional Belarusian dress originates from theKievan Rus'period. Due to the cool climate, clothes were designed to preserve body heat and were usually made fromflaxorwool. They were decorated with ornate patterns influenced by the neighboring cultures: Poles, Lithuanians, Latvians, Russians, and other European nations. Each region of Belarus has developed specific design patterns.cite webhttp://www.belarusguide.com/culture1/clothing/index.htmlBelarusian traditional clothingBelarusguide.com2013-04-29One ornamental pattern common in early dresses currently decorates the hoist of theFlag of BelarusBelarusian national flag, adopted in aBelarusian referendum, 1995disputed referendumin 1995.cite webhttp://fotw.fivestarflags.com/by.html#ornBelarus – Ornament, Flags of the WorldFotw.fivestarflags.com2013-04-29
article.heading: Cuisine
article.paragraph: Belarusian cuisineconsists mainly of vegetables, meat (particularly pork), and bread. Foods are usually either slowly cooked or stewed. Typically, Belarusians eat a light breakfast and two hearty meals, with dinner being the largest meal of the day. Wheat and rye breads are consumed in Belarus, but rye is more plentiful because conditions are too harsh for growing wheat. To show hospitality, a host traditionally presents an offering ofbread and saltwhen greeting a guest or visitor.Canadian Citizenship and Immigration Cultures Profile Project  Eating the Belarusian Way. Published in 1998. Retrieved 21 March 2007.

article.paragraph: see alsoBelarus at the OlympicsFile:Victoria Azarenka (9417885047).jpgthumbVictoria AzarenkaBelarus has competed in the Olympic Games since the1994 Winter Olympics. ItsNational Olympic Committeehas been headed by President Lukashenko since 1997; he is the only head of state in the world to hold this position.

Receiving heavy sponsorship from the government,ice hockeyis the nation's second most popular sport afterAssociation footballfootball. The national hockey team finished a surprising fourth in overall competition at the2002 Salt Lake City Olympics, and its players have been present in theNational Hockey Leaguein North America.Darya Domrachevais a leadingbiathlonbiathletewhose honors include three gold medals at the2014 Winter Olympics.

article.paragraph: mainTelecommunications in BelarusSee alsoCensorship in BelarusFile:State TV Belarus.jpgthumbBroadcasting center of state-run "ANT" TV-channel inMinskIn 2008, there were 3.718 million phone landlines used in comparison toNowrap8.639 millioncellular phones in Belarus. About two-thirds of all of the phone services are run on digital systems, and the mobile-cellularteledensityis about 90 phones per 100 persons. There are approximately 113,000 internet hosts in Belarus in 2009 to meet the needs of approximatelyNowrap3.107 millionInternet users.cite webhttps://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.htmlBelarus26 April 201021 April 2010[[The World Factbook]][[Central Intelligence Agency]]https://web.archive.org/web/20100424035944/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bo.html24 April 2010no

The largest media holding group in Belarus is the state-ownedNational State Television and Radio Company of the Republic of BelarusNational State Teleradiocompany. It operates several television and radio stations that broadcast content domestically and internationally, either through traditional signals or the Internet.cite webhttp://www.tvr.by/eng/about.aspAbout us, National State TeleradiocompanyTvr.by2013-04-29The Television Broadcasting Network is one of the major independent television stations in Belarus, mostly showing regional programming. SeveralList of newspapers in Belarusnewspapers, printed either in Belarusian or Russian, provide general information or special interest content, such as business, politics or sports. In 1998, there were fewer than 100 radio stations in Belarus: 28AM broadcastingAM, 37FM broadcastingFMand 11shortwavestations.

All media companies are regulated by the Law on Press and Other Mass Media, passed onNowrap13 January1995.Law On Press and Other Mass Media, Law of the Republic of Belaruswaybackhttp://www.law.by/work/EnglPortal.nsf/6e1a652fbefce34ac2256d910056d559/1f80c30387b1623dc2256dc00051dc63?OpenDocument20070928040724This grants the freedom of press; however, Article 5 proscribesslanderagainst the President of Belarus or other officials outlined in the national constitution.The Belarusian Government has since been criticized for acting against media outlets. Newspapers such asNasha Nivaand theBelaruskaya Delovaya Gazetahave been targeted for closure by the authorities after they published reports critical of President Lukashenko or other government officials.cite webhttp://www.eurozine.com/articles/2006-04-19-newsitem-en.htmlIndependent Belarusian newspaper "Nasha Niva" to closeEurozine.com2013-04-29cite webhttp://belarusian.minsk.usembassy.gov/policy20030530.htmlMedia Freedom in Belarus26 April 201030 May 20032003 Policy ArchiveUnited States Department of StateThe OSCE andFreedom Househave commented regarding the loss of press freedom in Belarus. In 2009, Freedom House gave Belarus a score of 6.75 (not free) when it came to dealing with press freedom. Another issue for the Belarusian press is the unresolved disappearance of several journalists.cite webhttp://www.freedomhouse.org/report/nations-transit/2009/belarusNations in Transit 2009 – Belarus26 April 20102009Freedom House
